2585×580 140 KB  Welcome to the one-stop shop for a TL;DR on everything discussed on the MakerDAO forum.  Online PDF Version available here.  Summaries reflect our views of the most noteworthy activities in MakerDAO. Disagree? Think something should be added? Leave a reply or send a PM.   Three-Point Summary ‘What is the most relevant information on the forums this week for MKR and Dai holders?’ 1. @MakerMan is retiring as a Delegate to focus on personal projects, while Delegate @Doo_StableLab has stepped down from the Growth Core Unit to concentrate on his Delegate duties. 2. @rune proposed a “unified DAO toolkit” for implementing nearly automated transparency, while @Hasu proposed a simpler alternative to the Endgame Plan. 3. Recognized Delegate @ultraschuppi made an interesting proposal for jumpstarting vault usage by slightly increasing the percentage fee applied when trading a stablecoin in exchange for DAI using the PSM.   News and Announcements  Endgame Decentralized Voter Committee Meetings: Wednesday, June 29, 9 pm CEST and Thursday, June 30, 9 pm CEST  Rune announced the agenda for both June 29th and June 30th DVC calls! June 29th’s call discussed the DVC concept, renaming of these concepts, and focus objectives for Core Units. Additionally, CES presented the current state of collateral onboarding and their opinions on priorities and focus objectives.  Watch the recording here.  Check out CES’ slide deck on the current state of collateral onboarding here.   June 30th’s call will focus on delegates and delegation.   Join here at 19:00 UTC.   Announcement - At end of term MakerMan will be retiring as a delegate.  “What has been created on Ethereum, I believe, has all the core elements to make a better world (both from a financial perspective, but also from a governance and people one).” Due to recent events, @MakerMan has announced that he will be stepping down as a Delegate to focus on writing a whitepaper for a personal project.  Doo_Upcoming Resignation from Maker Growth Core Unit  @Doo_StableLab announced that he would be stepping down from his position as a member of the Growth Core Unit to focus more of his time on Delegating work, minimizing conflicts of interest, and lightening the load on the Growth CU’s budget. The Growth team is now looking for a replacement; contact @Doo_StableLab, @joce_chang, or @nadia on the forum if you know someone who might be a good fit.  A Farewell to Lending Oversight  @luca_pro made a farewell post about the project they’ve been leading in recent months: the Lending Oversight Core Unit (LOVE), aimed at “developing state-of-the-art frameworks for internal checks and balances, acting as an additional line of defense within the DAO, and helping to educate the community.” While the proposed MIP39c2-SP33 did not pass, @luca_pro took the opportunity to reiterate his dedication to the Maker community and thank the many fellow DAO members who supported onboarding the LOVE Core Unit.  Meet Your Delegate #16 - pvl  Meet Your Delegate #16 with Delegate candidate @pvl will take place on July 7th at 3 pm UTC. Learn more about @pvl’s background in their platform, which will also be presented before the Q&A section of the event. Google Calendar Zoom Meeting Meeting ID: 896 9599 0453 Passcode: 838320  Pinned Posts  We’ve rounded up the pinned posts on the Maker Forum for easy access. These posts are primarily for accessing reference information and resources. Resources & Schedules   Office Hours List: Check when different Core Units hold office hours sessions open to the public.  All Available Guides: Lists all available Maker-related guides, from the Acronym Reference List to the Maker Operational Manual.  All Available Dashboards: Dashboards that aggregate and visually display data relating to MakerDAO and its activities. MakerDAO’s Discord Servers  The Votes and Important Dates Calendar: Details monthly and weekly governance cycle events, including all votes and reminders about important dates like freeze period deadlines, formal submission deadlines, and RFC deadlines.  The Calls Calendar: Lists MakerDAO calls and meetings.  Category Explanations These pinned posts provide a quick overview of the purposes of different tags on the Maker forums.   About the Guías category: Lists all translated guides for Latin America.  About the Discontinued Categories category: Locked forum area for admins to move decommissioned forum categories.  About the Public Calls category: Serves as a single place where members of MakerDAO can post information about calls and meetings that don’t fit into other categories  About the Research category: A place where people can post MakerDAO-related research that doesn’t fit into a specific category.  About the Guides category: Lists all the available guides at MakerDAO.  About the Dashboards category: Lists all the available MakerDAO dashboards.  About the Resources category: Lists common resources at MakerDAO, such as public calls, calendars, and dashboards.    Active Discussions  Unified DAO toolkit: Making transparency easy  Rune made a post responding to concerns that DAO members will no longer be allowed to talk to their colleagues under the Endgame Plan. He argues that we should have “maximum reasonable transparency” regarding the work Core Units are engaging in. All significant work interactions between independent Core Units must be carried out publicly and fully documented according to standardized procedures. Achieving this kind of transparency can help Maker achieve several goals, including:  Measuring results and evaluating performance in an unbiased way Ensuring the security and integrity of processes and documentation to avoid critical operational risks in the event of a Core Unit disappearing Verifying that free-market processes set the prices paid by Maker and that Core Units aren’t accidentally or intentionally creating vendor lock-in or monopolization  Rune proposes a “unified DAO toolkit” to achieve this level of transparency. This kit would comprise a software tool used for workflow tracking, similar to Jira or Trello, and a wiki-like governance information dashboard. These two components combine governance and operations under a single system and allow for built-in transparency for “free.”  Simple MakerDAO — Governance from first principles  Recognized Delegate @Hasu made a post outlining a series of governance changes to address many of the issues MakerDAO is currently facing. While he believes Rune’s Endgame Plan contains some good ideas, he wanted to provide a simpler alternative for the sake of competition. Hasu believes that Maker struggles with a lack of long-term vision and strategy and needs to find solutions for two primary issues going forward: 1. Maker’s identity crisis Multiple questions have been debated by the community for years—and are still being debated:  How much emphasis should we put on MKR holder profit vs. operating as a public good? What is the right balance between decentralization and efficiency? Should Maker stay isolated to crypto or expand to the real world? Should we continuously burn MKR vs. burning MKR tactically? Is Maker a bank? What is the right shape for MakerDAO (the organization)?  Hasu believes we must develop a unified vision for where Maker should be headed. 2. Maker’s governance crisis @Hasu argues that MKR holders and Delegates are overburdened and are expected to vote on every proposal without the adequate knowledge (due to the growing size and complexity of the Maker organization) or incentivization to do so.  The proposal for solving these problems involves two main components. 1. Creating a Constitution This Constitution would nail down a long-term vision for MakerDAO by defining:  Maker’s vision and North Star The rights and responsibilities of key stakeholders within the system Maker’s mandates (e.g., make money for MKR holders, create the most liquid decentralized stablecoin, and become the cheapest source of credit)  Benefits include:  Creating a rock-solid foundation of the underlying principles of Maker; the constitution defines those parts that are explicitly not subject to frequent change and from which other decisions (e.g., strategy or tactics decisions) derive Encoding in writing what we can’t encode in smart contract code Creating a yardstick against which all other parts of the decision supply chain (delegates, council, MAs, CU members) can be held accountable Cleanly separate the what (vision, goals) from the how (strategy) so they can be discussed and decided on individually   2. Establishing a Council of Makers The main goal of this component is to provide the strategy level of the governance decision-making chain with its dedicated role. The Council could be tasked with:  Setting a high-level strategy to reach the goals laid out in the Constitution Setting and allocating a budget Managing bigger DAO transactions like buybacks, dividends, DAO-to-DAO partnerships, and token/debt offerings  Specialization would be encouraged to avoid complications arising from the local knowledge problem.  Some implementation details and an impact outlook are available in the full post.  Governance Security Module (GSM) Adjustment [Informal Poll]  This Informal Poll aims to gather sentiment from the community on how to adjust the Governance Security Model (GSM) Pause Delay, which is designed to give MKR holders a chance to review all earmarked changes to the Maker protocol for malicious intent before the changes are enacted. Some community members believe the current delay of 48 hours is too short.  Can we justify the existential risk posed by PSM-USDC?  “If the DAO continues to exist at the will of Circle/USDC, then we need to justify it. If we can’t justify it, we need to change it.” Recognized Delegate @ChrisBlec made a post airing his concerns regarding the amount of DAI generated from USDC in the PSM and its associated risks. Pointing out that Circle, which issues DAI, has the power to “blacklist/freeze the USDC in the PSM without notice,” he believes we need to act immediately to develop a plan for mitigating existential risks introduced by this and similar situations. With this post, ChrisBlec is:  Requesting that CUs use this as a safe space to offer some realistic modeling & scenarios (PE, legal, any other relevant takes) regarding precisely what would happen if all USDC in the PSM got blacklisted/frozen. Asking staunch PSM supporters to justify the risk that the scenarios presented in Step 1 become a reality. Asking us to decide, as a DAO, whether or not the reasons to keep the PSM in its current state (or at all) are worth the risks and justifications that have been established.  Several suggestions were provided in the comments, including a well-thought-out reply from @monet-supply:  619×822 142 KB  Post note: Joao, USDC product lead at Circle, has responded to the thread by introducing his own thoughts on the topic.  Rethinking PSM-fees  Currently, fees for exchanging stablecoins for DAI (and vice versa) using the PSM are set at zero. This makes it easy to arbitrage using the PSM: If DAI is trading at $1.01, users can convert their USDC to DAI and sell it for a 1% profit. At the same time, native-crypto-backed vaults are losing momentum, with the appetite for leverage in the crypto market at a historic low. Furthermore, Maker recently reached its all-time highest stablecoin ratio at 80%. In light of this situation, Recognized Delegate @ultraschuppi believes it may be a good idea to raise the tin slightly—the percentage fee applied when trading a stablecoin in exchange for DAI. If the tin were raised to 1%, for example, this would make it so that arbitraging the depeg is only possible by minting DAI using real collateral, boosting vault usage.  Questions about MIP47 multisigs & Makershire  @ChrisBlec made another post with some unanswered questions about MIP47, which covers how MakerDAO multisigs work, and its relation to Makershire. If Makershire passes, 10,000,000 DAI belonging to MKR holders and entrusted to MakerDAO governance will be transferred to a 5-of-7 multisig. ChrisBlec believes the following questions must be answered for Maker to be acting responsibly and that the Makershire proposal (if passed) should be delayed until they are settled:  What rules, processes, and security will be utilized during the multisig ceremony? Will the ceremony be in-person or virtual? How will the rules, procedures, and security be enforced if virtual? How can the DAO be assured that the private keys and/or mnemonics securing each of the seven signing keys were generated clandestinely, have been infallibly secured throughout their existence, and were not compromised before being designated as a multisig signer? How will the community multisig signers prove to MakerDAO that the multisig keys are not being held in a hot wallet like Metamask (as has happened with numerous other multisigs)? What ongoing measures will MakerDAO be able to take to ensure that any future compromise of a multisig signer’s wallet becomes known to the DAO the moment that it happens? Who will be legally and financially responsible if five of the seven multisig keys are compromised, and the funds are stolen (as has happened with numerous other multisigs)? If MakerDAO governance decides to cancel Makershire and revoke the funds, what assurances does the DAO have that the multisig signers will act in the DAO’s best interests and return the funds? What measures are being taken to counteract the financial incentive that five of the seven community multisig signers have to collude, steal, or fake a theft from the multisig (as has happened with numerous other multisigs)?   [BEAR] CU Facilitators: Transparent and Proactive Cash Management  In a post related to this Signal Request, @adcv asks Core Units to:  Confirm the accuracy of actual expenses reported in the below on-chain snapshot Confirm on-chain snapshot of cash on hand and intent to return excess DAI to the DAO Provide an expense forecast through Q3 End (June, July, August, and September) Return all excess cash over three months of monthly forecasted spend  More aggressive returns that could be possible due to underspend relative to budget will be greatly appreciated     820×592 82.6 KB   820×592 82.6 KB   [Open-Discussion] What could be potential reasons for Donut switching from DAI to USDC for their Save program?  @TRUEMAKER wants to know why DeFi investing app Donut has chosen USDC over DAI for their “Save” program. @dbkcan questioned whether New York state’s recent stablecoin guidance may have led to the change, but @TRUEMAKER pointed out that “DAI is allowed in NYS too,” so the mystery remains. If you have an insight or idea into why Donut made the switch, share it in the comments.  SHCU | Reflections On Recent Events: A LOVE Letter  “If the path forward is centralized, hierarchical system control, Maker may be a successful enterprise, but it is not the vision I signed up for.” @aburban90, Facilitator of the Strategic Happiness Core Unit, made a post regarding what they view as a potentially coordinated effort to pass the proposal to onboard the LOVE Core Unit, almost enabling a “move towards centralization.” They cite that close to one-third of MKR participated in the vote: “Where did all these new ‘Yes’ votes come from?”  Thoughts on Multichain DAI Liquidity Strategy  @monet-supply published an in-depth post about the growing activity on non-Ethereum and layer-2 chains and how this momentum could affect DAI. The post calls for Maker and its community to take a more proactive approach to generate and safeguarding liquidity on external domains. After a detailed explanation covering why DAI liquidity across domains is beneficial for Maker, the current mechanisms used to support cross-chain liquidity, and important KPIs and metrics, monet-supply outlines some ideas for improving DAI liquidity across the blockchain space:  Liquidity incentives: It could make sense to pursue limited scope incentives to bootstrap DAI liquidity on external domains and get it to the point where DAI markets become self-sustainable through organic usage. Partnerships: Maker can partner with external protocols to support DAI liquidity and integration within their apps. Community Visibility: Because these users can maintain their existing custody scheme (e.g., using a hardware wallet or setting up a multisig), they don’t face the same governance and custody risks that MakerDAO itself would when deploying assets cross-chain. Sharing these opportunities more accessible way could help increase DAI adoption without direct costs to the DAO.   [Informal Poll] DAI borrowing incentive ideas that the DAO could test?  This informal poll seeks to gather interest in ideas the DAO should test to incentivize DAI borrowing for new wallets. The options are:    Seeking Consensus ‘Yo, do you even signal?’  [BEAR] Building Financial Resilience & DAO Targets  June 23rd’s Governance and Risk call dove into the cash flow forecast that was followed by discussions on various scenarios to calculate Maker’s runway in the event of sustained unprofitability. In response, Strategic Finance is asking whether MKR holders should be able to guide targets for bear-market expense cuts through on-chain polls? If so, then these on-chain polls would be framed as follows: “What target level of Recurring Net Protocol Income profitability (defined as rNPI / Recurring Revenues averaged over a preceding three calendar month period, excluding MKR vesting and liquidation income) should the DAO set to drive budget cuts?”  Positive (> 5%) Break-even (±5%) Negative (minimum three years of runway at any time) No change   1757×670 118 KB  This Signal Request ends today! Final Vote Breakdown:  1680×797 142 KB   Signal Request: LP our AAVE and ENS with ETH on Uniswap v3  In response to MakerDAO’s receipt of a large quantity of ENS tokens after last year’s ENS airdrop, this Signal Request gauges community sentiment about LPing Maker’s AAVE and ENS in the treasury with ETH. Selling airdrops may reflect poorly on MakerDAO; putting them to work in liquidity pools may enable Maker to generate additional revenue from the ENS airdrop without jeopardizing community sentiment or rendering MakerDAO ineligible for future airdrops. About $90k in stkAAVE tokens are also currently unutilized. This Signal Request will run until June 30th, 2022. Current vote breakdown:  1707×742 165 KB   1707×742 173 KB   Immediately Onboard BUSD & Introduce 0% PSM  This urgent request is to expedite a MIP6 & PSM launch for BUSD to diversify DAI’s collateral backing. Maker currently holds a majority of exposure to USDC. If Circle (USDC) is underwater for whatever reason, our entire collateral base could default. In response, @aburban90 is asking the community to immediately onboard BUSD as collateral, which will be used as a temporary alternative in an effort to phase out USDC or at least diversify the risk of collateral defaulting. However, Andrew will likely have to create a new request using the MIP6 collateral application template; as mentioned here. The Signal Request will run until July 9th, 2022. Current vote breakdown:  1705×660 86.8 KB   1705×682 88.9 KB   1705×672 87.5 KB    Ongoing Initiatives ‘Oh my god, this is taking ages; why can’t things be simple?’ Maker Operational Manual - @GovAlpha-Core-Unit releases the launch of the Maker Operational Manual and invites all members and Core Units to reach out if they wish to provide any help or documentation to add to the Manual. Recognized Delegate Requirements - LongForWisdom writes a detailed overview of the current requirements and application system to become a delegate in the Maker community. Check out this thread for more posts related to delegation. Where to Find Opportunities at MakerDAO and Open positions at MakerDAO - Looking for job opportunities at MakerDAO? Perfect! Please comment on the thread if anybody has additional information on unique hiring practices or job listings. Refer them here. Collateral Status Index - Confused about the current status of the various collateral types discussed recently? Think something should be added? Leave a reply or send a PM.  Online PDF Version available here.  Authors: @nothsa, @alec, and @artem_gordon   Three-Point Summary ‘What is the most relevant information on the forums this week for MKR and Dai holders?’ 1. @AstronautThis’s calculations show that the current Emergency Shutdown Module (ESM) Threshold is safe, but the community may want to consider disabling the ESM anyway. 2. The Risk Core Unit has announced v3 of the Maker Risk Dashboard, adding support for Vault type, PSM, D3M, oracle, liquidation, and whale data. 3. Tickets for the Daivinity party at EthCC in Paris are available. Reserve yours here!   News and Announcements  Announcing Maker Risk Dashboard v3  The Risk Core Unit recently made a post announcing v3 of the Maker Risk Dashboard. In addition to a new design, new pages for Vault type, PSM, D3M, oracle, liquidation, and whale data have been created.  For this third iteration, the team has:  Redesigned the website to provide a better and more accessible user experience Abstracted data, concepts, and models to reduce complexity and simplify the dashboard Added new features to provide access to data not previously available in v2   DAIvinity EthCC Paris Tickets  If you’re planning to attend the Daivinity party at this year’s EthCC, message @Leggevents on the forum or comment in this thread to be allocated a pre-release code. The event will take place at Bridge Club in Paris on July 19th with doors opening at 21:00.   twitter.com    🇫🇷🚀DAIvinity🚀🇫🇷 @Daivinity  eventbrite.ca/e/daivinity-ti…   5:53 PM - 6 Jul 2022           13             Meet Your Delegate #16 - pvl  @pvl will be presenting their Delegate platform and hosting an AMA on July 7th at 3 pm UTC. Among other things, @pvl hopes to help Maker integrate the following as DAO practices:  Web3-native intelligence for protocol stewardship, collateral onboarding, and treasury management Provably optimal infrastructure funding mechanisms Web3-native community support tools  Zoom Link Meeting ID: 896 9599 0453 Passcode: 838320  Meet the Dai Foundation Board during EthCC  The Dai Foundation board will be hosting an in-person community meeting during this year’s EthCC for anyone interested in learning more about the Dai Foundation.  Unfortunately, tickets are currently sold out.  MakerDAO Actual Expenses vs Budget - May 2022  @adcv of the Strategic Finance Core Unit posted the May update for monthly Core Unit expenses and a forecast for the subsequent three months. In summary:  DAI expenses were up to 3.2M in May, 0.6M lower than forecasted. Forecasted expenses are expected to stabilize to around 3.7M/month by June, a 44M annual run-rate. Oracle gas expenses continue to trend lower due to decreased network congestion, as well as OCU’s work to minimize them.     MIP41c4-SPxx: Immunefi Security Core Unit Facilitator Onboarding - IS-001  @psychonaut has been added as a co-Facilitator for Core Unit IS-001: Immunefi Security. In his own words, @psychonaut explains: “I have worked as Deputy Facilitator for Immunefi Security since its inception on Dec 2021 and, during part of its incubation period under SES, two months prior (Oct and Nov 2021). I have taken charge of the accounting, written status updates, and contributed to our core unit’s goals. Our current Facilitator, @travinimmunefi, continues to lead with long-term strategic planning but is stretched thin by his many other responsibilities. This MIP formalizes what is essentially already the status quo.”  Guidance on how to specify Copyright in software produced for MakerDAO  A new document outlining how to attribute copyright for MakerDAO software is available here. The document covers how to assign copyright to the Dai Foundation, the guardian of MakerDAO’s intangible assets, and how to ensure copyright information is visible on GitHub.   Active Discussions  [Informal poll] Disable the Emergency Shutdown Module  The Emergency Shutdown Module (ESM) enables a minority of MKR holders to shut down the protocol by depositing enough MKR to reach the ESM Threshold, currently set at 150,000 MKR. In a possible attack vector opened up by this mechanism, an attacker could short the MKR token, trigger the ESM, and close their position once the MKR price drops. The ESM Threshold should be set so this attack would be unprofitable. Using a series of calculations, post author @AstronautThis demonstrates that given the amount of MKR available for borrowing on other protocols (among other methodological assumptions outlined in the full post), the current ESM Threshold is high enough to make such an attack unprofitable. Given that: 1. There is currently no consensus surrounding the situations that would merit triggering the ESM, and 2. in a crisis, MKR holders are more likely to sell their MKR than deposit it in the ESM to be burned, it may be worth considering the question of whether we need an ESM at all. Should the ESM be disabled by community consent? If the protocol did need to be shut down, it would be subject to the GSM Pause Delay, currently set to 48 hours.  Questions for Core Units about intangible assets - for review and comment  @sorenpeter of the Dai Foundation made a post compiling a list of budget- and ownership-related questions for the community to ask when a Core Unit MIP has been posted as an RFC. The goal is “to ensure that there is focus on avoiding that single operators can control important MakerDAO assets and communication channels.” Some of the questions include:  Have you acquainted yourself with the Dai & Maker Trademark Policy, so you know how to utilize the Dai, Maker, and MakerDAO names and logos? Which types of tangible and intangible assets will you produce with the funding from MakerDAO? Will the assets produced using MakerDAO funding be available as public goods for the whole DAO?   [Vault-Discussion] NonSC Crypto-Backed Loan Optionality  Continuing the ongoing discussion surrounding the PSM and its collateral, @TRUEMAKER made a post and informal poll to center dialogue around finding an optimal balance between on-chain and off-chain collateral. @TRUEMAKER proposes shifting focus to ETH-based vaults to increase the volume of non-USDC-backed assets, thereby lowering the percentage of USDC-backed assets. In particular, they propose introducing a “vault-holder optionality” feature that would give users a one-time annual option to transition between same-currency vaults, which differ in collateralization requirements and stability fees.  Potential Benefits  A higher ratio of DAI generated from ETH/BTC; less reliance on USDC/RWA Increased vault duration and retention Pricing optimizations that include a more defined range between ETH-based vault types Align pricing with evolving market conditions in a formulaic way A better customer experience leads to longer-term and/or higher-use customers Incentivizes new vault creation Reduction in loan defaults of bad debt  Potential Risks  Temporary stability fee reduction Lower liquidation fees Coding execution leading to faulty migration   End-Game Summary - Part 3  To aid his understanding and increase the accessibility of the ideas for everyone, @LongForWisdom posted a summary of Part 3 of @rune’s Endgame Plan. The structured, bullet-pointed summary:  Stresses the simplicity of the process Points out budget challenges as the primary area of concern Highlights the need for best practices to achieve a general separation of powers  MetaDAOs may be the best way to compartmentalize this risk   Introduces ideas around DAO2DAO operations  Under this model, CUs would no longer be companies or groups hired directly by Governance, but as a service provided by MetaDAO’s to Maker.    Follow @LongForWisdom’s Endgame Index List for a listing of Endgame-related posts and @LongForWisdom’s summaries.  Proposal of END Capital to be Attestor for Bank Participation Vaults  END Capital has expressed interest in becoming an “Attestor” for Maker, dealing with underwriting responsibilities and fiat on and off-ramps for DAI. In their own words: “Our END Capital team has over 40 years of combined experience originating, underwriting, and investing in asset-backed loan portfolios in aggregate totaling in excess of 500 million transactions.”  Unified DAO toolkit: Making transparency easy  In this post, @rune argues that we should have “maximum reasonable transparency” regarding the work Core Units are engaged in. All significant work interactions between independent Core Units must be publicly and thoroughly documented according to standardized procedures. @rune proposes a “unified DAO toolkit” to achieve this level of transparency. This kit would comprise a software tool used for workflow tracking, similar to Jira or Trello, and a wiki-like governance information dashboard. These two components combine governance and operations under a single system and allow for built-in transparency for “free.”   Seeking Consensus ‘Yo, do you even signal?’ Surprisingly, there are no active signal requests at the time!  image1477×727 76 KB    Ongoing Initiatives ‘Oh my god, this is taking ages; why can’t things be simple?’ Maker Operational Manual - @GovAlpha-Core-Unit releases the launch of the Maker Operational Manual and invites all members and Core Units to reach out if they wish to provide any help or documentation to add to the Manual. 2582×577 135 KB  Welcome to the one-stop-shop for a TL;DR on everything discussed on the MakerDAO forum. Summaries reflect our views of the most meaningful activities in MakerDAO. Disagree? Think something should be added? Leave a reply or send a PM.  Online PDF Version available here.  Authors: @nothsa and @artem_gordon   Three-Point Summary ‘What is the most relevant information on the forums this week for MKR and Dai holders?’ 1. The Strategic Finance Core Unit released a MakerDAO financial report for June. 2. MIPs have been submitted for offboarding both the Strategic Happiness and Immunefi Core Units. 3. The Oracles Core Unit submitted an innovative budget proposing a voluntary budget reduction in exchange for one year without further cuts. Bonus! Keep an eye out for a Forum update by DUX about the Delegate Contract Migration feature on the Portal, coming soon!   News and Announcements  Financial Report 2022-06  The Strategic Finance Core Unit has published its MakerDAO financial report for June.  Summary Overall Net Protocol Income was 6.7M DAI, +33% from May and -23% from June 2021. Annualized ROE on a rolling 6mo basis has begun sliding from 70-80 toward 30-40%.  After-effects from rapid deleveraging in Q2 continue to ripple through the crypto economy (LUNA → Celsius → 3AC → etc.) ETH/BTC prices continued their decline throughout June  ETH/DAI: 1,955 to 1,024 WBTC/DAI: 31,611 to 18,718 This has driven a substantial amount (impact of -1.4M DAI) of the decline in recurring revenues as vaults liquidated and users covered positions   Collateral locked is also in sharp decline as major institutional users exit lending amidst broader market deleveraging  ETH locked in protocol from Ξ2.2M to Ξ1.5M WBTC locked in protocol from ₿34K to ₿63K driven by vaults protecting positions; as of 11-Jul-2022, collateral is back to ₿39K (due to Celsius loan repayment)   Total interest income decreased from 4.3M to 2.4M (-44%) month on month Overall income up on liquidations from a volatile month – from 8.6M to 9.5M (11%)  The full report is packed with data, visualizations, and insights.  MIP41c5-SP9: Facilitator Offboarding (SH-001) and MIP41c5-SP10: Facilitator Offboarding (IS-001)  MIPs for offboarding both the Strategic Happiness and Immunefi Core Units have been submitted by @CodeKnight and @Ippy, respectively. Subproposal MIP40c3-SP76, @CodeKnight explains the motivation for offboarding Strategic Happiness. In short, the proposal’s supporters believe the Strategic Happiness Core Unit represents an unnecessary expense during the bear market, noting that its budget tripled during the last approval cycle and was already contentious before the bear market began. GovAlpha posted an impact analysis in the comments:  844×267 67.4 KB  Subproposal MIP40c3-SP77 offers similar reasoning, arguing that offboarding the Immunefi Core Unit and engaging contributors’ services on a contractual basis is a preferable alternative expected to result in more than 12,000 DAI per month in personnel cost savings.  Off-Chain Proposal Bounties Round Up #1  The first monthly summary of winning governance authors and initiatives for the Off-Chain Proposal Bounties initiative has been published. This initiative aims to incentivize the submission of concrete governance proposals by distributing rewards in DAI to authors of successful Signal Requests and MIPs. The current monthly reward pool is set at 6,000 DAI. While there were many successful Signal Requests, MIPs, and Subproposals in June—more than in both April and May—none met the eligibility criteria, and no rewards have been distributed via this initiative yet.   DAO Resilience Improvement Initiative – Status Update  The DAO Resilience Improvement Initiative, now a joint effort of the DUX, GovAlpha, GovComms, and SES Core Units, aims to achieve two primary goals:  Improve the DAO’s financial and operational resilience Experiment with emergent vision and strategy for MakerDAO  This status update covers some changes to the format of the initiative and outlines some of the current work being done. The original format of the initiative presented several challenges:  Timing: With the bear market coming, “forceful short-term developments have overtaken sustained efforts of continuous improvement.” Meeting fatigue Lack of sustained coordination and buy-in from multiple participants: Difficult to achieve with an initiative started by a single Core Unit  To address the last issue, SES has recruited several other Core Units to get involved with the initiative to focus on decentralized operations, which encompasses tasks such as:  Organizing and improving the decentralized governance processes that drive MakerDAO operations Improving the signal of what MKR holders want to prioritize and providing them with the tools to express which direction they support Developing mechanisms to build and maximize consensus about MakerDAO vision and strategy, combined with effective execution  Current work in progress includes a vision alignment questionnaire for Delegates and a collaborative project with Stanford Professor of Political Economy and Political Andrew Hall.  Announcement: Delegate Migration  The upgraded Governance Portal is set to launch today, July 14th. Delegate contracts are nearing expiry and require action from both delegates and their delegators. Your MKR will never be at risk during the migration; however, you are strongly encouraged to migrate if applicable. The DAO’s delegation system is based on VoteDelegate smart contracts, which expire annually by design. These expired contracts cannot participate in governance, though any deposited MKR can still be withdrawn - even after expiry! Governance Portal The DUX CU has developed a new Governance Portal feature that informs users when action is required and facilitates the migration process for delegates and delegators. A successful migration establishes a link between the old and new owner address, which is used to aggregate participation metrics (profile markdown, performance, vote, and comment history). The goal is a smoother, more intuitive UX for all delegates and governance participants. Steps for Delegates   Prepare a different owner address for the new delegate contract (note: the new owner address cannot already own a delegate contract). Whilst connected with the current delegate contract owner address, submit the new address in the migration flow and wait for confirmation by DUX CU. Switch to connecting the new address to the Governance Portal to resume the migration process. Generate a new delegate contract. Migrate any of their own delegated MKR, and encourage their delegators to migrate.   Steps for Delegators When delegating MKR to a new or expired contract, delegators will see a banner at the top of the Governance Portal prompting them to migrate their delegation. Check your active delegations from their head to the ‘Migration’ page. This page lets users check if any of their delegations have expired or renewed. They can then easily undelegate and redelegate between the active options.   Active Discussions  [Informal Poll] Voluntary Budget Adjustment in exchange for 1 Year Guaranteed Budget  Last week, the Oracles Core Unit submitted an interesting budget proposal. Discussion surrounding ways to lower expenses during the bear market, including especially many different proposals for modifying Core Unit budgets, has taken center stage in recent months. With this in mind, the Oracles Core Unit has cut its proposed budget by 10% compared to last year’s budget. Given the uncertainty around the budget situation, the team has included a clause to avoid having its budget cut beyond this self-imposed 10%: If the reduced budget is approved, the Oracles Core Unit will be exempt from further budget reductions for 12 months. Alternatively, the proposal offers voters the option to vote for the same budget as last year but is subject to any DAO-wide cost-cutting initiatives that may be implemented in the future. With this post, @Doo_StableLab aims to gauge community support for this proposal and the potential benefits of applying it to other CUs. He also provides a set of pros and cons:  Pros  Cuts costs Gives CUs the freedom to choose where to cut within their budget More certainty (and thus better planning) Fairer if the same amount cuts all CUs   Cons  As this functions as a budget cut and a budget freeze, CUs’ function might decrease Might be unfair for CUs that run lean budget requests compared to CUs that request more than they actually spend If the cut rate is the same across CUs, CUs are disincentivized from cutting more than the set rate, even if they have the ability If the cut rate is the same across CUs, some CUs might not be able to withstand the cut if their initial budget is already very tight   End-Game Summary - Part 4  @LongForWisdom has released Part 4 of their ongoing summary of @rune’s Endgame Plan. These summaries are intended to:  Help get @LongForWisdom’s head around the Endgame Plan so they can form an opinion on it Improve accessibility of what is an incredibly complicated set of concepts and proposals  This post covers MetaDAOs (key aspects, types, and related profit opportunities), increasing MakerDAO’s Layer2 penetration, getting Maker “into the metaverse,” and tokenomics. Doo_Thoughts as a Hawk Delegate  Recognized Delegate @Doo_StableLab published a post sharing his thoughts on the ongoing discussion around Core Unit budgeting. Zoom Link Meeting ID: 882 8655 0832 Passcode: 690611   Seeking Consensus ‘Yo, do you even signal?’  Budget Re-allocation & Core Unit Accountability Framework  Should the DAO use a broad-based cut or tactical reallocation process to adjust budgets? During the July 20th, 2022, Decentralized Voter Committee meeting, the Strategic Finance Core Unit (SF) presented two options for the DAO to choose between adjusting budgets and returning to breakeven operating cash flow:  1035×715 407 KB  Option 1: Broad Cut has the advantage of requiring little overhead to be executed quickly and effectively. It has the disadvantage of treating all Core Units equally, regardless of performance or existing spending patterns. Option 2: Tactical Reallocation, recommended by SF, involves allocating budgets based on merit. The waterline mental model  Governance decisions should be triaged according to whether they make changes “above the waterline”—reversible changes that justify a more experimental approach—or below it, meaning the changes are irreversible and may result in irreparable damage. Postmortems  Curve LP Token Oracle Manipulation Vulnerability - Emergency Response Postmortem  On April 14th, the Curve team notified the Protocol Engineering Core Unit (PECU) about a reentrancy manipulation vulnerability in the oracle used for the steCRV (ETH-stETH) pool. In response, Maker stakeholders coordinated to freeze the affected oracle until a solution could be implemented. The solution was included in the April 22nd Executive Vote, and full functionality of the pool was re-enabled when the Executive was executed on April 27th. This postmortem explores how the incident was handled by PECU, exploring both what went well:  The response from Recognized Delegates External engineering relationships A delay on the debt ceiling increases A generally cautious approach to finding the right solution  Furthermore, what needs improvement:  Response time Recognized Delegate contract Communication with the DAO and other stakeholders Unclear leadership Voting portal UI limitations that delayed the resolution process by ten minutes Potentially inaccurate importance score Unclear relationship with Immunefi Security and the role they should play when security risks are identified   Curve LP Token Oracle Manipulation Vulnerability Technical Postmortem  This postmortem of the steCRV pool vulnerability focuses on the technical aspects of how the incident was processed and resolved. In short, the get_virtual_price function of the steCRV oracle returned an incorrect value if it was called at the same time as a withdrawal from the pool, which enabled the possibility of a reentrancy attack. The solution the Protocol Engineering Core Unit settled on was to deploy a fixed oracle contract with functionality for reverting a transaction in the case of a reentrancy attack launched from the Curve pool. Forum Recap        News and Announcements  ConsenSys Delegate Platform  Major Ethereum development studio ConsenSys has published its Delegate Platform. Fixed rates strategies and mechanisms in the Decentralized Collateral Scope  Decentralized collateral backing is achieved through borrower participation, but borrowers are more likely to opt for fixed-rate loans, which makes them an essential resource for Deco and Creator clusters. Considering this, @rune proposes two incentive mechanisms that will increase the number of borrowers and benefit MetaDAOs that do not offer fixed-rate products. As a first mechanism, revenue share bonuses are offered to users as an incentive:  Only applicable to Maker Core Vaults that do not support MetaDAO token yield farming. A retroactive revenue share is provided for the stability fees earned from such vaults.  A vault’s duration is used as a measure of creditworthiness.   MetaDAO and ecosystem actor frontends are eligible for a revenue share opportunity in addition to the standard 25% stability fee revenue share. Parameters contain a 10% bonus accrued over one year.  Example 1: A vault that pays 1,000 DAI in SF over a year generates a 10% bonus + 25% (SF) for the 12 months, resulting in a total of 35% revenue share - 350 DAI. Example 2: A vault that pays 500 DAI in SF over six months generates a 5% bonus plus the standard 25% (SF) for the 6 months, resulting in a total of 30% revenue share - 150 DAI.    As a second mechanism, we will have a fixed-rate module:  Regulated through the Decentralized Collateral Scope Framework.  Managed by Maker Governance Votes in accordance with advice provided by Decentralized Collateral Core Units. Utilizes protocols such as Deco and similar products to target a fixed rates strategy for decentralized assets and their vaults. The Decentralized Collateral Core Units will develop a targeted portfolio based on data and frameworks provided by the Stability and Liquidity Scope. Active Discussions  Lessons for Maker from the Collapse of HUSD  In the wake of HUSD losing its peg after Huobi announced it would be delisting the stablecoin, Recognized Delegate @Doo_StableLab shared some takeaways for the MakerDAO community.  Not all centralized stablecoins are the same  Some assert that all centralized stablecoins operate similarly, especially those using Paxos for custody. In the case of HUSD, there was a lack of transparency and communication: While Paxos initially supported the stablecoin, it was later revealed that the US dollars backing the coin were actually stored in Huobi Trust.  Risky stablecoin management has consequences  Stories abound of HUSD aggressively seeking increased market share by selling the coin at favorable rates. After many Asian partners went bankrupt or shut down under similar circumstances to the Celsius situation in the West, some of this investment may have “turned sour” as redemption requests ramped up, resulting in an undercollateralized HUSD. In conclusion, Doo believes that it’s good to utilize our own stablecoin collateral; however, we should be cautious in how we manage these stablecoins, or else we may also face liquidity trouble. Announcements & Updates  Build Your Own ALM Model  To help MKR holders and governance participators understand the potential effects of onboarding different types of collateral, the Strategic Finance Core Unit has released simple asset-liability management (ALM) spreadsheet for community members to experiment with. The post explains how to use the sheet and what each data set represents. So if you’re curious how financials would be affected by a particular colla  1035×573 64.8 KB  The yellow cells are intended to be edited to explore the consequences of using different values for these parameters. The top part of the spreadsheet features three different sections displaying several metrics derived from the parameters mentioned above:  Item 1: A simplified income statement. Key takeaways from this project include:  The Surplus Buffer is a limitation without an obvious solution. MakerDAO does not have enough capital for all the current proposals.     Active Discussions & Proposals  MANA-A intermediate parameter change proposal  Risk associated with the MANA-A vault type has increased dramatically due to a decrease in collateralization as the price of MANA fell in recent months. One particular whale appears to control most or all of the existing vaults and has not been very active. The liquidation of one of these vaults could result in cascading liquidations if the vaults are not protected. The Risk Core Unit recommends decreasing Maker’s exposure to MANA by adjusting parameters to incentivize debt repayment and further incentivizing vault owners to prevent liquidation events. Specifically, the team proposes:  Decreasing DC to 3M DAI from the current 10M Significantly increasing SF to 50% from the current 7.5% Increasing the liquidation penalty to 30% from the current 13%   Kao Protocol - Seed Investment / Venture Debt  This post asks MakerDAO for a $60K investment in Kao Protocol, a DAO and DeFi protocol in which users can stake NFTs to earn yield. The team plans to issue real estate NFTs representing fractionalized ownership shares in African real estate. Recognized Delegate @Doo_StableLab stepped in to share his thoughts on the proposal:  919×122 22.3 KB   Why’s growth core unit is not focusing on Indian & Vietnam markets?  @ihsotas expresses his concern on DAI growth rate and adoption in India and Vietnam. Research & Reports  Vault User Research: Survival Analysis  This research report from the Risk Core Unit dives into churn dynamics, investigating how well Maker vault users are retained over time. The analysis is broken down into six primary areas:  Vault Count Distribution split by Activity State   903×310 19 KB  Only about 9% of the ~28,000 vaults opened historically remain open. The median tenure for churned vaults—defined as the difference in months between when the vault was opened and when it decreased its position below 10,000 DAI—is about four months. The median tenure for retained vaults is about a year.  Vault Survival Curve split by Entity Level (Wallet vs. Vault Level)   903×481 16.9 KB  The y-axis shows the percentage of still active vaults, and the x-axis shows the number of months since the vault was opened (its tenure). Takeaways:  Less than 5% of vaults/wallets tend to remain active after 36 months. 30% of wallets remain active after a year of usage, similar to vaults. The representative/median tenure before churning is five months.   Vault Survival Curve split by Collateral Symbol   903×480 19.6 KB  stETH has the best early retention, followed by WBTC and ETH.  Vault Survival Curve split by Liquidation Churn State   713×455 32.1 KB  It stands to reason that experiencing a liquidation could significantly lead to vault churn. However, the data shows a negligible connection between vaults that experience liquidation and early churning rates.  Vault Survival Curve split by Vault Type (ETH Collateral)   903×478 20.6 KB  This chart looks explicitly at ETH. ETH-C (low fee, high liquidation ratio) and ETH-A (medium fee, medium liquidation ratio) appear to be retained better, while ETH-B (high fee, low liquidation ratio) is the worst-retaining vault type. This tracks with the idea that more risk-tolerant vault users are more likely to churn due to being more likely to optimize for capital efficiency across the ecosystem.  Vault Survival Curve split by Debt Size   903×481 29.7 KB  A clear relationship exists between improved retention and maximum vault size. 70% of vaults with 100M+ DAI exposure remain active after one year of usage, compared to 25% of vaults with 10,000 DAI to 100,000 DAI after the same time. Announcements & Updates  StarkNet changes for 2022-10-26 Executive Spell [1, 2]  The executive spell, which took place on October 26, updated the StarkNet bridge in light of changes to StarkNet’s fee structure. To avoid the possibility of infinite transactions, fees are now charged by the Starknet sequencer for any L2 transactions and L1 → L2 messages. To accommodate this feature, the L1DaiBridge.deposit and L1DaiBridge.forceWithdrawal functions of Maker’s StarkNet bridge were modified.  Candidates for Dai Foundation Board Member Election Poll  This post announces two candidates, @Daimon-Law and @0xbocaJ, seeking election to the Dai Foundation Board in accordance with the Foundation’s commitment to including members appointed by MakerDAO. Paul Imseih—known as Daimon-Law on the forum—is an Australian and UK lawyer with over 25 years of experience working mainly in the technology and intellectual property sectors. His candidate statement is available here. Jacob Minne—0xbocaJ on the forum—has worked in blockchain since 2012. His legal career has focused on IP counseling and litigation. Jacob’s candidate statement is available here.  Agreement between MakerGrowth and GnosisDAO  This document posted by the Growth Core Unit is an initial proposal for review regarding adding Gnosis’ GNO token as a collateral type. Scope   Introduction of GNO-A vault in MCD GnosisDAO continuation of borrowing activity with highly liquid decentralized assets (e.g., stEth) in MCD Further development in a second phase through joint collaboration efforts of the DAI ecosystem, liquidity, and userbase in GnosisDAO-controlled projects, including but not limited to Gnosis Chain (GC)   Vault Parameters   DC-IAM Line (max DC): 5M Liquidation ratio: 350% Stability fee: 2.5%   In accordance with the agreement, Gnosis must remain an active MCD Vault user, maintain no less than 75% of GnosisDAO stablecoin borrowing activities with highly liquid assets, and utilize the GNO-A debt ceiling as soon as possible.    Active Discussions & Proposals  Endgame Plan next steps: 2023 milestones for MetaDAO Launch  This post from @rune outlines some Pregame phase Endgame Plan milestones we hope to see in 2023. These building blocks must be in place to launch the on-chain components of MetaDAOs. The list of Pregame products includes:   EtherDai token wrapper deployment Elixir Balancer pool deployment MetaDAO ERC20 token deployments (one for each MetaDAO) Meta Elixir Uniswap v2 pool deployments (one for each MetaDAO) Anti-Reflexivity Mechanic deployments (one for each MetaDAO)  Linear token sales mechanism to prevent price spikes   Dai Farms (one for each MetaDAO) EtherDai Farms (one for each MetaDAO) MKR Farms (one for each MetaDAO) Metanomics I deployment  70,000 MKR emitted per year, with 60,000 funneled directly to the Meta Elixir of each of the MetaDAOs   Various dss-kiln and proxy contract deployments to manage accounts and token flows for MetaDAOs   We’ll also need a minimum viable product of MetaDAO frontends, which will require these features:   Access to all Dai Farms Access to opening Maker Vaults (including EtherDai Vaults) Access to all EtherDai Vault Farms Access to all MKR Farms MVP of the Easy Voter Frontend that is required for users who wish to farm with MKR, as they need to first delegate through this frontend to be able to farm with MKR Support for MetaDAOs adding their products or external services   Further products needed to move beyond the Pregame phase include setting in place the MetaDAO cluster journey—from Cluster announcements (several of which have already been made) to normal operation—as well as an Endgame Constitution and Scope Frameworks.  Adjusting Dust Parameter (November 2022)  With Ethereum gas prices having dropped significantly, this post from the Risk Core Unit’s @monet-supply makes a case for lowering the minimum permitted debt—or dust—for Vaults. This could enable more accessibility and increase user acquisition. As evidenced by Compound and Aave, neither of which has a minimum dust limit, any potential losses from bad debt are likely to be offset by user acquisition gains. The proposed changes come in two options: Option 1: This option includes a broad reduction of dust limits across Vault types.   Reduce dust for ETH-A, WBTC-A, and WSTETH-A to 5,000 DAI Reduce dust for ETH-C, WBTC-C, and WSTETH-B to 2,500 DAI Reduce dust for ETH-B and WBTC-B to 15,000 DAI Reduce dust for CRVV1ETHSTETH-A, LINK-A, YFI-A, MATIC-A, MANA-A, and RENBTC-A to 10,000 DAI Leave dust unchanged for UNIV2USDCETH-A, UNIV2DAIUSDC-A, GUNIV3DAIUSDC1-A, and GUNIV3DAIUSDC2-A   Option 2: This option includes more limited dust reductions, targeting large-cap Vault types with the highest potential utility for small users while limiting the risk of liquidation losses.   Reduce dust for ETH-A, WBTC-A, and WSTETH-A to 7,500 DAI Reduce dust for ETH-C, WBTC-C, and WSTETH-B to 3,500 DAI Reduce dust for ETH-B and WBTC-B to 25,000 DAI Leave dust unchanged for CRVV1ETHSTETH-A, LINK-A, YFI-A, MATIC-A, MANA-A, RENBTC-A, UNIV2USDCETH-A, UNIV2DAIUSDC-A, GUNIV3DAIUSDC1-A, and GUNIV3DAIUSDC2-A    Enabling the DSR  This post from the MakerDAO Open Market Committee (MOMC) points out that yield spreads between DeFi and TradFi are growing and that this trend is not likely to abate any time soon. The post explores increasing the DAI Savings Rate (DSR) to distribute some of the extra revenue that Maker is likely to see in the near future to existing DAI holders who are currently not earning any yield. Increasing the DSR would significantly boost yields in protocols like Aave and Compound, which have integrations with the DSR, incentivizing USDC suppliers to migrate to DAI instead. If this happens successfully, we can expect an accompanying increase in Net Protocol Income.   Calculating the value of RWAs and the surplus buffer  In this post, Recognized Delegate @CodeKnight points out the importance of having a defined way of calculating the specific value of the Surplus Buffer is calculated in light of MIP84: Activate Protocol-Owned Vault Emulation. This calculation will be critical when it comes to working with bonds. @tadeo stepped in to inform us that the Data Insights Core Unit is working on a model to accurately reflect actual revenue, including RWAs. Authors: @nothsa and Artem Gordon PDF version   Three-Point Summary ‘What is the most relevant information on the forums this week for MKR and Dai holders?’ 1. The Collateral Engineering Services Core Unit shared a post outlining what the team has learned regarding RWA collateral onboarding and RWA management, plus recommendations for improving processes going forward. 2. The GovComms Core Unit announced its transition to become an Ecosystem Actor in effort to promote the success of the pre-launch phase of the Endgame plan. 3. monkey.irish submitted a MIP offboarding himself as the Core Facilitator of the Collateral Engineering Services Core Unit. MIPs have also been submitted nominating Interim Facilitators and a replacement for monkey.irish. Forum Recap:          Announcements & Updates  November 23rd Endgame Call: Timeline and roadmap for organizing Maker Governance based on DVCs, the Endgame Constitution and the 12 Scopes  Yesterday’s Endgame Call focused on the practical aspects of governance reform outlined by the Endgame Plan. The main topics included:  Establishing a nearly immutable Endgame Constitution that all mandated actors, professional ecosystem participants, and official infrastructure must be compliant with Bootstrapping the 12 Scope Frameworks that will be the foundational tool for all governance decisions and contain any and all mutable complexity of Maker Governance Bootstrapping the Decentralized Voter Committee (DVC) concept, starting with three launch DVCs that will start to delineate the simple fundamental choices available to MKR holders for determining their preferred governance style Operationalizing the three urgent priorities of the Pregame phase, which are:  Building community momentum for MetaDAO participation Attracting Maker Core RWA talent Attracting a new generation of professional delegates    A rough 2023 roadmap includes the following:   Q1:  Drafting the Constitution and Scope Framework Decisions on the cleanup of legacy infrastructure, product lines, collateral, etc. Clustering participants by Scope:  MKR Holders/DVC members Delegates Full-time specialized Professionals (Council or Tribunal)      Q2:  Passing the first MIP version of the Constitution and some or all of the initial Scope Frameworks DVCs begin to operate formally New versions of each Scope Framework updated based on the discussion and research done during the quarter Governance-style decisions made based on voter support of each of the 3 (or more) DVCs    Q3 and Q4 will iterate on the procedures carried out in Q2. By Q4, the first post-launch quarter, Scope Frameworks will be used to regulate and interact with MetaDAOs in a live environment with voter incentives in place.       The Future for GovComms – a message encouraging voters to pass our current budget proposal  With the pre-launch phase of the Endgame plan moving forward, Core Units must begin to wind down and adequately transition. @Davidutro announced that becoming an Ecosystem Actor is the best approach for the GovComms Core Unit. In this new ecosystem, GovComms can propose project-based engagements to both MakerDAO and independently, serving as a powerful supporting actor. The Core Unit will continue to support Maker Core during what we all hope will be a reasonably smooth transition. With this now on the table, the GovComms team hopes for the support of their current budget proposal (on-chain right now).    Active Discussions & Proposals  Executive Inclusion: Starknet bridge limit  The StarkNet Engineering Core Unit requests that the increased debt ceiling of 1M DAI (up from 200K DAI) for the StarkNet bridge, which has already been approved, be included in an Executive Vote.  Un-Fuzzing the Endgame Plan at EthGathering Barcelona  @ultraschuppi, @flipflopflapdelegate, and @rspa return with another episode of Drinks with MakerDAO Delegates! In this episode, the trio convenes at EthGathering Barcelona to dive into and “un-fuzz” the basic mechanics of the Pregame Phase of the Endgame Plan. Check it out here for an overview or refresher.  CES Core Unit & Facilitator Offboarding/ Onboarding lollike [1, 2, 3, 4]  Several MIPs have been submitted regarding offboarding @monkey.irish as the CES Core Unit Facilitator and onboarding a new Facilitator and Interim Facilitator(s). monkey.irish has chosen to resign from the position due to what he views as a value misalignment, stating that “this project lacks the fundamental qualities of why I committed myself to blockchain, crypto, DeFi, and the overall industry.” monkey.irish has nominated @zmtong and @dbkcan as interim Facilitators, and @juan has already submitted a MIP nominating @lollike as the new Facilitator due to his long tenure with MakerDAO and “vast knowledge” of the MakerDAO protocol and ecosystem.  Collateral On-Boarding and Management of RWAs - Lessons Learned/Recommendations  In this post, dbkcan of the Collateral Engineering Services Core Unit (CES) shares what the team has learned regarding onboarding and managing Real World Assets (RWAs) and makes some recommendations for working with RWAs going forward. The first topic covered is the MIP21 Toolkit, which was produced before the formation of CES and intended to provide tools for experimenting with the on-chain abstraction of small RWA transactions. While this toolkit has been helpful in the rapid onboarding of new RWAs, more complex recent deals have required significant tweaking and the creation of new components to be executed successfully. In short, CES has identified three primary areas in which MIP21 is deficient:  Scalability of transactions Transparency Lack of collateral management  More specifically, issues include:  Collateral valuation reliance on centralized off-chain counterparties  This means that until a Vault is closed, Maker’s only way of determining the value of an RWA is based on reporting from the borrower Ways to mitigate this issue include:  Proactively requiring new borrowers/proposers to incorporate in their proposals how they plan to automate and create DAO-friendly reporting terms and technical approaches Providing details on how external APIs and oracles can be used to automate collateral management     Liquidation and enforcement of collateralization ratios is a manual process with no single point of responsibility  Without automating Vault liquidation, there is a significant risk that any problems with the underlying RWA collateral will be detected late Ways to mitigate these concerns include:  Creating an RWA token wrapper to facilitate the availability of basic financial instrument data Using oracles, trustees, and centralized APIs to update on-chain data Modifying MIP21 to use relevant on-chain data to provide automated early warnings/liquidation triggers based on debt serviceability     RWA stability fees do not provide objective early warning signals for potential problem vaults and could significantly overstate the surplus buffer  Ways to mitigate this issue include:  Short term: restrict usage of accrued Vault stability fees for RWA Vaults expected to remain open for more than 6-12 months to only the lowest risk RWA asset transactions Medium-term: bring more data on-chain to facilitate the automatic verification of payments and/or facilitate early warning of potential collateral impairment       Poll to move forward with the commercial risk, legal, technical, and other work necessary to onboard the deal outlined in MIP90  This request to submit a poll aims to gather sentiment regarding making the assessments required to onboard the deal outlined in MIP90: Liquid AAA Structured Credit & Money Market Fund . The full terms of the deal are available in the post, but in short, the deal involves opening a DAI 600MM RWA Vault that will acquire USDC via the PSM and acquire USD 600MM of diversified, AAA (or equivalent) rated Structured Credit and Money Market Funds.    Research, Reports & Assessments  BlockTower Credit CES Domain Team  This Collateral Engineering Services Core Unit post represents the team’s official evaluation of BlockTower Credit. The key takeaways are:  The technical smart contract risk is considered “Medium” due to the implementation:  Utilizing contracts outside of Maker’s scope Not being extensively reviewed by Maker Involving the increased operational overhead of managing four Vaults instead of a single Vault, resulting directly in Executive Spells and increasing technical risk   Clear processes for assessing the ongoing performance of the collateral will be required for required manual monitoring Limiting the amount of maintenance work required in Executive Spells for future deals will reduce technical risk     Ongoing Initiatives ‘Oh my god, this is taking ages; why can’t things be simple?’ Maker Operational Manual - GovAlpha Core Unit releases the launch of the Maker Operational Manual and invites all members and Core Units to reach out if they wish to provide any help or documentation to add to the Manual. Authors: @nothsa and Artem Gordon PDF version   Three-Point Summary ‘What is the most relevant information on the forums this week for MKR and Dai holders?’ 1. LongForWisdom shared an idea for a new voting system aimed at providing a more consensus-building approach to governance and easing polarization. 2. Retro has been officially appointed as the Interim Facilitator of the Collateral Engineering Services Core Unit. 3. Hexonaut opened the floor for a discussion of existential asset exposure and shared ideas for mitigating large losses. Forum Recap:          Announcements & Updates  Moving 30th Nov and 7th Dec Executives to Friday of each week  PECU and StarkNet are moving the mainnet deployments for the following two executives:  Wednesday November 30th to Friday December 2nd. Wednesday December 7th to Friday December 9th.  Both executive votes for the current and following weeks will take place on Friday rather than Wednesday to ensure that these final executive votes for 2022 can be safely deployed.  Retro as Fallback Interim Facilitator for CES  We are pleased to announce that @Retro has been selected to serve as Interim Facilitator of the Collateral Engineering Services Core Unit and will focus on the following immediate actions:  Re-enable and stabilize CES resources and contributors. Obtain a clear understanding of work requirements, timelines, and deliverables. Reconfigure CES’s multi-sigs to meet MakerDAO’s best practices, and review operational expenses. Begin planning for the future state of CES resources. Define the Interim Facilitator timeline.  Fortunafi Update - Pipe Technologies This post from @Fortunafi rebuts recent rumors about the protocol’s exposure to crypto miners. The post reports that Fortunafi has “no exposure to crypto miners whatsoever.” Attention RENBTC-A Users: Collateral Offboarding The RENBTC-A vault type is being offboarded. An Executive Vote on Wednesday, December 7th, or later will trigger the final parameter adjustments to complete the offboarding process. GovComms Core Unit Budget Rejected The GovComms Core Unit—the team behind this publication—had its budget rejected in a November 22nd vote. The team will continue its core work until officially winding down. Some community members have demonstrated support for a potential merger between GovComms and GovAlpha, and Core Unit Facilitator @Davidutro has expressed interest in the CU moving into the role of Ecosystem Actor during the Endgame.    Active Discussions & Proposals MIP4c2-SP30: Amend Interim Facilitator Appointment Process MIP4c2-SP30 contains a series of amendments addressing two primary issues with the current Interim Facilitator process:  Lack of timely resolution: The Fallback Process that kicks in when the initial process fails takes at least a week, long enough for major issues to arise. Lack of flexibility: Governance Facilitators cannot modify processes under atypical circumstances.  A Better Prioritization System for MakerDAO In this post, @LongForWisdom of the GovAlpha Core Unit presents a voting system—a combination of positional voting and the approval voting system currently in place in Maker governance—that will enable individual voters to express more fine-grained preferences than the current approval voting system alone. This system could be used to identify work priorities and in the Endgame to prioritize work on scopes, within DVCs, and within MetaDAOs. GovAlpha hopes this system will promote consensus building and reduce polarization from contentious votes. Discussion on Existential Exposure and Mitigation In this post, @hexonaut of the Protocol Engineering Core Unit calls for a discussion to clarify what we mean by “existential exposure”—when does “really bad” single asset exposure become “existentially bad”—and to develop ways of mitigating it. According to hexonaut’s proposed definition, we have “existential exposure” when “we take on bad debt to such a degree that DAI permanently loses its peg in an irrecoverable way.” Hexonaut’s idea for mitigating large losses involves allowing temporary under collateralization and leaving bad debt on the books in the case of a large loss that hits a certain threshold, then filling the gap over time via slow issuance of MKR tokens, debt, or revenue. Parameter Changes Proposal - PPG-OMC-001 - 24 November 2022 The latest parameter change proposal from the MakerDAO Open Market Committee recommends a series of updates to normalize debt ceiling IAM parameters during the bear market, reducing risk and unnecessary excess capacity. The proposed changes are:   ETH-B: Reduce line to 250 million DAI:  Reduces tail risk. Prevents excessive accumulation of risky debt.    WSTETH-A: Increase line to 500 million DAI and reduce gap to 15 million DAI:  Allows for further growth. Reduces maximum exposure to possible Lido tail risks.    WSTETH-B: Increase line to 500 million DAI and reduce gap to 15 million DAI:  Allows for further growth. Reduces maximum exposure to possible Lido tail risks.    WBTC-A: Reduce line to 500 million DAI, reduce gap to 20 million DAI, and increase ttl to 24 hours:  Limits excessive exposure growth. Reduces throughput, helping limit potential losses from Bitgo-related tail risks.    WBTC-B: Reduce line to 250 million DAI, reduce gap to 10 million DAI, and increase ttl to 24 hours:  Limit potential tail risk exposure.    WBTC-C: Reduce line to 500 million DAI, reduce gap to 20 million DAI, and increase ttl to 24 hours:  Reduces total throughput to 50 million DAI per day, which should be enough to meet recent demand levels while significantly reducing Bitgo risk exposure.    LINK-A: Reduce gap to 2.5 million DAI:  Existing 7 million DAI gap parameter no longer provides any additional protection.    MANA-A: Reduce line to 0 DAI:  Reduces liquidity and market risk.    YFI-A: Reduce gap to 1.5 million DAI:  Normalizes the YFI-A gap against the recently lowered line parameter.    Compound v2 D3M: Activate with 2% bar and line of up to 10 million DAI:  Idiosyncratic risks have increased lending protocols in the past month, and a smaller line of 10 million is more appropriate.    GUNIV3DAIUSDC1-A: Reduce line to 100 million DAI:  Prevents further growth. Helps achieve a decline in exposure while minimizing the UX impacts of potential increases in the Stability Fee.    GUNIV3DAIUSDC2-A: Reduce line to 100 million DAI:  Helps realign Maker’s stablecoin positions with current opportunities.    UNIV2DAIUSDC-A: Reduce line to 100 million DAI:  Prevents excessive growth. Helps realign Maker liquidity toward optimal positioning.    PSM-USDP-A: Increase tin to 0.1% and reduce line to 450 million DAI:  Limits increases in USDP exposure to concentrate Maker’s liquidity position in assets that provide more value to the protocol.    PSM-GUSD-A: Increase tin to 0.1% and reduce tout to 0.1%:  Disincentivizes further increases in exposure.    The post also explores the idea of increasing the DAI Savings Rate to incentivize retention or increase DAI supply.
